author: By Amelia Nierenberg, Matthew Haag, Maria Cramer and Olivia Bensimon
title: No Victims Found Under 7-Story Bronx Apartment That Partially Collapsed
description: Firefighters found no victims after searching the debris left by the corner of the building that collapsed. Two people had minor injuries.
content: Firefighters said they had searched the 12-foot-tall pile of debris left by the collapse of a seven-story building in the Bronx on Monday afternoon, and found that no one had died or been severely injured.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman
title: Countries Most at Risk Call Proposed Climate Agreement a ‘Death Warrant’
description: The working draft made public at the U.N. summit in Dubai would not commit nations to phasing out the fossil fuels that are dangerously heating the planet.
content: Environmental groups and negotiators from countries that are most vulnerable to climate disasters assailed a draft of a final agreement, made public at the United Nations climate talks on Monday, that fell short of calling for a phaseout of fossil fuels.The long-awaited draft said nations “could” take actions to slash greenhouse gas emissions, including “reducing both consumption and production of fossil fuels” by 2050, in line with what the science says must be done to avert the worst consequences of global warming.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Who Should Run Universities?
description: In the wake of a controversy at the University of Pennsylvania and Harvard over antisemitism, a debate has arisen over whether academics are best suited to lead big schools.
content: After weeks of criticism from alumni, donors and public officials — and disastrous testimony on Capitol Hill — Liz Magill stepped down as the University of Pennsylvania’s president on Saturday over her stance on combating antisemitism. Meanwhile, the heads of Harvard and M.I.T. remain under pressure, with some of their fiercest critics continuing to call for them to resign, too.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gaya Gupta, Hiba Yazbek and Ameera Harouda
title: ‘We are all sick’: Infectious Diseases Spread Across Gaza
description: Cold, wet weather combined with a lack of clean water, toilets and food have fueled a spike in respiratory, stomach and other ailments, and the sick are left struggling to recover, health officials say.
content: Infectious diseases are ravaging the population of Gaza, health officials and aid organizations said on Monday, citing cold, wet weather; overcrowding in shelters; scarce food; dirty water; and little medicine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Evan Moffitt
title: The Gallery That Has Never Lost an Artist
description: Monika Sprüth and Philomene Magers built one of the art world’s most powerful businesses by not following conventional wisdom.
content: For several weeks this past autumn, a fashionably dressed woman could be seen in the window of a London art gallery stooping to pick up a half-dozen designer shopping bags. A digital print on a mirror made by the artist Sylvie Fleury, the woman was permanently frozen in the act, her bare midriff impervious to the rain outside. A collection of real bags on the floor before her doubled the optical illusion for passers-by, who might have been carrying their own bags from the nearby Versace or Dolce & Gabbana stores. But the gallery, Sprüth Magers, is not the kind of place where most people can casually drop in and buy something; the artworks sold there fetch prices in the tens to the hundreds of thousands. If Fleury’s work poked fun at the view that art is just a commodity, it was also a nostalgic reflection on the moment the empty shopping bags were first shown by the gallery, in 1991 — a time when neither she nor her dealers could have afforded a permanent storefront in Mayfair.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Sale
title: Financial Questions to Discuss Before Moving In With Your Partner
description: What would you do if you won the lottery? How do we stop having this same fight about money? And much more.
content: This article is part of a Modern Love project on the intersection of money and relationships.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: The Rise in U.S. Traffic Deaths
description: What’s behind America’s unique problem with vehicle crashes?
content: For most of the automobile’s first century of existence, it became safer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dani Blum
title: How Much Weight Comes Back After Stopping a Weight-Loss Drug?
description: A new study on tirzepatide, the compound in Mounjaro and Zepbound, gives an early indication.
content: Zepbound, the newly approved weight loss drug, hit the market this month. People seeking out the medication may have to stay on it for the foreseeable future — potentially, for the rest of their lives — if they want to keep the weight off, new research confirms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aurelien Breeden
title: Macron Suffers Surprise Setback Over Immigration in France
description: The country’s lower house of Parliament unexpectedly passed a motion to reject a government immigration reform bill, leaving its future uncertain.
content: President Emmanuel Macron of France suffered an unexpected setback on Monday as lawmakers brought his government’s immigration overhaul bill to a screeching halt, casting fresh doubts on his ability to get key legislation through Parliament.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By MB Caschetta
title: The Devastation of Disinheritance
description: My father’s decision to cut me out of his will shocked me. Could the damage ever be repaired?
content: This essay is part of a Modern Love project on the intersection of money and relationships.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Carballo
title: Using A.I. to Talk to the Dead
description: Some people are using artificial intelligence chatbots to create avatars of departed loved ones. It’s a source of comfort for some, but it makes others a little squeamish.
content: Dr. Stephenie Lucas Oney is 75, but she still turns to her father for advice. How did he deal with racism, she wonders. How did he succeed when the odds were stacked against him?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: Unpacking California’s Wild Weather Year
description: A conversation with Judson Jones, a New York Times meteorologist and reporter, about the state’s “pretty astonishing” precipitation throughout 2023.
content: It’s Monday. We talk to Judson Jones, a New York Times meteorologist, about California’s “pretty astonishing” precipitation throughout 2023. Plus, in Los Angeles, the “coroner to the stars” has the last word.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Coscarelli
title: YSL Defendant Shannon Stillwell Is Stabbed, Delaying Young Thug Trial
description: Mr. Stillwell, known as SB or Shannon Jackson, is among the six defendants currently on trial in the racketeering and gang conspiracy case underway in Atlanta.
content: Shannon Stillwell, a co-defendant of the superstar rapper Young Thug in the racketeering and gang conspiracy case currently underway in Atlanta, was stabbed in jail on Sunday night, a lawyer for Mr. Stillwell said, delaying the blockbuster trial.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Caramanica
title: Nicki Minaj, a Role Model for Herself, and Others
description: On “Pink Friday 2,” the rapper remains a star navigating hip-hop on sometimes untested terms. But even as she’s receded from the center of the genre, her lessons remain.
content: Before the arrival of Nicki Minaj in the late 2000s, only a handful of female rappers had ever released platinum solo albums: Lauryn Hill, Missy Elliott, Lil’ Kim, Foxy Brown, Da Brat, Eve. Despite their innovations and artistry — or maybe because of them — the genre had narrow expectations and accommodations for the expression of women, and often pitted them against each other, as if the space for anyone but men was zero-sum.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: Golden Globes 2024 Nominations: ‘Barbie’ and ‘Oppenheimer’ in Front
description: “Barbie” led the nominations with nine, followed by “Oppenheimer” with eight. In the television categories, “Succession” had the most with nine.
content: To many, the Golden Globe Awards are a perfect example of Hollywood’s two faces.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Schmitt
title: Air Force Disciplines Personnel After Teixeira Investigation
description: Members of Airman Jack Teixeira’s unit failed to take proper action after becoming aware of his intelligence-seeking activities, an inspector general inquiry found.
content: The Air Force has disciplined 15 military personnel for dereliction of duties after an inquiry into Jack Teixeira, an Air National Guardsman who was accused this year of posting classified documents online.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David W. Dunlap
title: With Issue No. 60,000, One Correction Comes to Mind
description: In 1999, a news assistant’s number crunching revealed that The Times had gotten ahead of itself.
content: On Tuesday, Dec. 12, The New York Times will print its 60,000th issue.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse McKinley
title: Want Your Couch Back? Pay Up, Said Movers Who Ran Ransom Scheme
description: After customers’ belongings were on the trucks, the shape-shifting Brooklyn company would demand more money to unload them, prosecutors said.
content: Any New Yorker who has ever moved has experienced the transient terror of putting all one’s belongings into a moving truck, sweating out the precarious hours poised between one apartment and another, calling neither home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Cumming-Bruce
title: Despite Wars, Earthquakes and Hurricanes, U.N. Cuts Appeal for Aid
description: With pledges already lagging badly for this year, the global organization said that it had been forced to pare down its request for 2024 to focus on only the most life-threatening cases.
content: The United Nations has cut its appeal for humanitarian aid in the coming year by nearly 20 percent, saying that it has to focus on only the most urgent cases, even as the number of people facing conflict and climate emergencies grows sharply.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy W. Peters, Dana Goldstein and Rob Copeland
title: Harvard’s Governing Board Nears Resolution on President’s Future
description: An announcement was expected on Tuesday about the future of Claudine Gay, the university’s president, who some donors and alumni say should be removed.
content: Harvard’s governing board on Monday was nearing a resolution that would allow its president, Claudine Gay, to remain in her job, according to two people with knowledge of the discussions. But those discussions were ongoing as of late Monday night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Watergate Salad Makes a Comeback
description: The 1970s-era dish made with pistachio pudding mix, canned pineapple and mini marshmallows has caught the curious eye of the TikTok generation.
content: At an office Thanksgiving potluck in Dallas last month, employees showed off their home cooking (and their catered shortcuts): There was spicy mac and cheese and roasted brussels sprouts, candied bacon and gumbo.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: Why Defenders of Harvard’s President Are Focused on Academic Freedom
description: The principle is highly valued by many at American universities, but critics say it is sometimes invoked to dodge repercussions.
content: The petition that emerged on Sunday as Claudine Gay, the president of Harvard University, faced escalating pressure to resign took only two sentences to make its case to the institution’s leaders.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola
title: Iran Puts E.U. Official From Sweden on Trial
description: The European Union and Sweden have called for the immediate release of Johan Floderus, who has been detained in Tehran for about 600 days.
content: Iran has put a European Union official from Sweden on trial for allegations that include spying for Israel and a charge that could carry the death penalty, according to Iranian state media, prompting renewed calls for his release.
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: Dec. 11, 2023
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Dec. 11, 2023.
content: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: What’s Next for Interest Rates? An Era of ‘Peak Uncertainty.’
description: Federal Reserve officials could keep all options on the table at their meeting this week, even as data shape up according to plan.
content: When Jerome H. Powell, the Federal Reserve chair, takes the stage at his postmeeting news conference on Wednesday, investors and many Americans will be keenly focused on one question: When will the Fed start cutting interest rates?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Nechepurenko
title: Navalny Misses Court Date, Raising Alarm Among His Supporters
description: The Russian opposition leader had been scheduled to appear before a district court via a video link on Monday. His spokeswoman said his allies had not heard from him for more than five days.
content: Aleksei A. Navalny, Russia’s most prominent opposition leader, who is currently serving a 19-year sentence in a Russian penal colony, missed another court date on Monday as his allies expressed concern at not having heard from him for more than five days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Mervosh
title: What to Know About Claudine Gay, Harvard’s Embattled President
description: Dr. Gay is the first Black president and second woman to lead Harvard. She faces calls for her removal over her testimony on antisemitism.
content: The president of Harvard, Claudine Gay, is facing the biggest test of her career, as the university’s governing board met behind closed doors on Monday amid calls for her removal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Nunn, Tjada D'Oyen McKenna, Jan Egeland, Abby Maxman, Jeremy Konyndyk and Janti Soeripto
title: The U.S. Must Change Course on Gaza Today
description: Global leaders, and especially the U.S. government, must understand we cannot save lives in Gaza under these conditions.
content: We are no strangers to human suffering — to conflict, to natural disasters, to some of the world’s largest and gravest catastrophes. We were there when fighting erupted in Khartoum, Sudan. As bombs rained down on Ukraine. When earthquakes leveled southern Turkey and northern Syria. As the Horn of Africa faced its worst drought in years. The list goes on.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner and Avishag Shaar-Yashuv
title: Ravaged Israeli Border Community Ponders: What’s Next?
description: Kibbutz Kfar Aza was devastated in the Hamas-led assault of Oct. 7, with its residents killed and kidnapped. Some see the prospects of its rehabilitation as a barometer for Israel’s future.
content: The kibbutz’s pub looks much as it always has. Trophies won by the communal village’s soccer team, the Kfar Aza Foxes, line a shelf above the bar. Residents, young and old, gather to swap news, share a drink or play a game of pool.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Don Clark
title: New York Plans to Invest $1 Billion to Expand Chip Research
description: The move is aimed at drawing $9 billion in corporate investment, as New York jockeys to host a new national semiconductor technology center.
content: Gov. Kathy Hochul of New York announced on Monday a plan to invest $1 billion to expand chip research activities in Albany, N.Y., as the state aims to continue as a global semiconductor center.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Iverson
title: 2023’s Crossword Constructor Debuts
description: In 2023, 90 puzzle makers will have their first New York Times Crossword published.
content: As the end of the year approaches, it’s fun to look back at our debut puzzle makers. We’re scheduled to publish 90 new constructors by the end of the year, which is nearly a record.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
title: There’s a Limit to How Much Weaseling Around You Can Do
description: Even in Washington.
content: Gail Collins: Hey, Bret, would you hate it if I asked for a couple of predictions for 2024?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason DeParle
title: Record Rent Burdens Batter Low-Income Life
description: More tenants than ever spend half or more of their income for shelter, leaving less for everything else, taking an emotional toll and leaving some without a place to call their own.
content: To understand how rising rents punish families of modest means, look no further than the queen-size bed that Jessica Jones and her three children share in her mother’s living room, where each night brings a squirming, turning tussle for space in a house with no privacy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora
title: As Zelensky Heads to Washington, Russia Targets Kyiv With Missiles
description: The Ukrainian leader will be appealing for more military support from the United States as an emboldened Russia steps up its attacks on his country.
content: As President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine heads to Washington on an urgent mission to rally flagging Western support for his nation, the Russian military on Monday targeted the Ukrainian capital with the most intense salvo of ballistic missiles in months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Febos
title: Was My Boyfriend Financially Controlling? Was My Girlfriend?
description: The common denominator between the two relationships had not been gender or sexual orientation. It had been me.
content: This essay is part of a Modern Love project on the intersection of money and relationships.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Somini Sengupta
title: The Climate Summit Scene: 70,000 People and a Nightly Light Show
description: Outside the negotiating rooms, COP28 is part trade fair, part lobbyist jamboree and part debate tournament.
content: There are two climate summits taking place in Dubai. One is the gathering of bleary-eyed, sharp-tongued diplomats parsing over every word and comma in the international declaration that is expected in the coming days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: No Ortolans Were Hurt During the Making of This Film
description: ‘The Taste of Things’ with Juliette Binoche, a nonalcoholic sparkler in a magnum, holiday stollens and more food news.
content: “The Taste of Things,” a French food film, will be shown in theaters this week in order to qualify for the Oscars and to make you really, really hungry. The 145-minute film by Tran An Hung, starring Juliette Binoche and Benoit Magimel, is based on the 1920 novel “The Life and Passion of Dodin-Bouffant, Gourmet” by Marcel Rouff, inspired by the French gastronome Jean Anthelme Brillat-Savarin, who gave his name to a cheese and a cake. The film is set at a modest château in the Loire region, the centerpiece of which is the robust kitchen where Dodin-Bouffant and his cook, Eugénie, prepare sumptuous meal after meal for Dodin’s small coterie of gourmands, as their own love story gently simmers. The pièce de résistance is a classic pot-au-feu. The chef Pierre Gagnaire was the consultant for the cooking, and in an interview in New York he said “everything is real; there was no faking.” (Not quite: There was backup gas fuel for the wood-burning stove, and small quail stood in for ortolans, a delicacy that is illegal.) He said the stars knew how to cook and “jumped right in.” Ms. Binoche told me that the food “haute cuisine but not pretentious.”  From Dec. 13 through 20, there will be a menu at Frenchette, in TriBeCa, with three dishes from “The Taste of Things”: a ballotine of duck, pot-au-feu and baked Alaska ($90 or à la carte).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Cameron
title: Man Accused of Sending Death Threats to Ramaswamy Is Arrested in New Hampshire
description: Tyler Anderson of Dover was jailed and the authorities seized firearms after tracking the threatening texts to his phone and home address, officials said.
content: Federal authorities arrested a New Hampshire man, charging him with threatening to kill Vivek Ramaswamy and his supporters, the Justice Department said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Proulx
title: What Do You Appreciate About Winter?
description: Some love it; some hate it. What foods, rituals, activities and festivities help you embrace the colder months?
content: Winter is nearly here in the Northern Hemisphere. Is this a season you look forward to each year? Or do you dread the onset of these dark, cold months?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: Golden Globes 2024 Snubs and Surprises: ‘Past Lives,’ Taylor Swift and More
description: The Korean American drama from Celine Song got four nominations, while Swift’s concert film got one. “The Color Purple” was overlooked for best musical.
content: The nominations for the 81st Golden Globes, announced Monday morning, brought good tidings for box-office titans “Barbie” and “Oppenheimer,” though some of the other contenders hoping to break through were dealt an early setback.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Can Recycling’s Problems Be Fixed?
description: Readers react to an essay that acknowledged the system is broken and offered solutions. Also: Campus protests; glamorizing guns; Times issue No. 60,000.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Philipps
title: Did Army Blast Exposure Play Role in Maine Gunman’s Rampage?
description: Medical scientists and the military are looking into whether Robert Card’s psychological collapse was linked to brain damage from his role as a grenade instructor.
content: After a 40-year-old Army Reservist named Robert Card went on a shooting spree in Lewiston, Maine, in October, his community grasped for answers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Genevieve Ko
title: The Best Way to Cook Steak for Holiday Parties
description: Starting on the stove, then finishing in a low oven, ensures rosy meat with charred crusts, Genevieve Ko writes.
content: There’s an undeniable urge to roar — or at least growl — when setting a thick steak into a ripping hot pan. Hearing the hard hiss of the sizzling fat is satisfaction enough, but then the smell of charred meat follows fast, and it’s pure pleasure from there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Knvul Sheikh
title: What You Need to Know About Sleeping Pills
description: A guide to the different types of medications for treating insomnia, their risks and when experts recommend using them.
content: About a third of adults around the globe say they sometimes struggle to fall asleep or stay asleep. If you’re one of them, you may have tried sleep medications to find temporary tranquillity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ryan Lenora Brown
title: ‘I Refuse to Be Old’: The 81-Year-Old Runner Who Became a South African Celebrity
description: Octogenarian athletes are not completely unheard-of in ultrarunning, but Maros Mosehla’s speed has made him a local legend.
content: On June 11, Maros Mosehla lined up with 16,000 other runners on the start line of the Comrades, a 56-mile footrace that began outside the red brick City Hall in Pietermaritzburg, South Africa. Mosehla, a wispy runner, 5 feet 2 inches tall, did not stand out from the crowd of athletes who had gathered to run just farther than the equivalent of two marathons through the misty winter morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By D.W. Gibson
title: In Brooklyn, Brownstone Dreams Start With One-Bedroom Rentals
description: A family of four lived in a tiny apartment while they looked for something bigger. They bought a place, but it needed work. So it’s back to a small rental.
content: “We’ve been living out of boxes for two and a half years,” said Susie Kwak Ting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gia Kourlas
title: Ailey Looks Back to Black Joy and Longing With 1930s Jazz
description: As part of its New York City Center season, Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater presents premieres by Amy Hall Garner and Elizabeth Roxas-Dobrish.
content: The dancers don’t so much step onto the stage in Amy Hall Garner’s “Century” as burst within it like a glitter bomb, showering the space in pink and gold. For “Century,” her first work for Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, performed on Friday at New York City Center, it’s clear that Garner doesn’t merely know a party when she sees one — she knows how to dream one up. A metallic curtain hangs in the back as dancers, looking like fuchsia flowers, vibrate from their shoulders to their feet like petals caught in a breeze.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
title: Why Sunak Faces One of His Toughest Weeks as U.K. Leader
description: The prime minister testified at an official inquiry into the Covid pandemic on Monday while also defending a flagship immigration policy from rebels in his own party.
content: Prime Minister Rishi Sunak of Britain embarked on one of the most politically fraught weeks of his tenure on Monday, facing a mutiny against his flagship immigration policy while testifying before an official inquiry into the coronavirus pandemic about whether he had contributed to driving up infections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: Space Station to Earth: Houston, We Have Found the Tomato
description: The NASA astronaut Frank Rubio grew a tomato in space, but then it disappeared. Suspicion trailed Mr. Rubio for months, but he was proved innocent.
content: The NASA astronaut Frank Rubio returned to Earth in September after completing the longest single spaceflight for an American astronaut and had to confront one small, red mark on his legacy: He had lost a tomato somewhere in the International Space Station.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Camille Elemia
title: What It Feels Like to Be the Target of China’s Water Cannons
description: The Philippines invited journalists on a mission to provide fuel to fishermen in disputed waters of the South China Sea amid tensions between Beijing and Manila.
content: The Filipino fishers on wooden boats waved at our vessel, a Philippine fisheries boat, from less than a mile away, but no one on our ship dared to move. Encircling us were two Chinese Coast Guard ships and five Chinese militia vessels.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simon Romero and Jody García
title: Guatemala’s Antigraft Crusader Won in a Landslide. Will He Actually Take Office?
description: Bernardo Arévalo, the most progressive leader to get this far in decades, faces a barrage of legal attacks aimed at preventing an orderly transfer of power.
content: When the anticorruption crusader Bernardo Arévalo won a landslide victory in Guatemala’s presidential race, voters streamed into the capital of Central America’s most populous country to celebrate. But as Mr. Arévalo’s foes intensify efforts to bar the president-elect from taking office just weeks from now, the mood on the streets has changed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ed Yong
title: Reporting on Long Covid Taught Me to Be a Better Journalist
description: Covering long Covid solidified my view that science is not the objective, neutral force that it is often said to be.
content: In the early months of the Covid-19 pandemic, when many people who are now still sick were first infected, the common wisdom was that the coronavirus either sent you to an intensive care unit or, more commonly, caused mild symptoms that resolved after two weeks. But when my sister-in-law got infected in March 2020, she was still burning with fever after three weeks, then six, then more. In this newspaper and elsewhere, young and formerly healthy people shared stories about surviving but not recovering. When I interviewed scientists and clinicians about these lingering symptoms in May, most expressed surprise. “That’s unusual,” one said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Kolata
title: New Drugs Can Fix Teenage Obesity, but Young People Don’t Get Them
description: Pediatricians are hesitating to prescribe medicines like Wegovy, citing their newness and uncertainties around them.
content: Dr. Edward Lewis, a pediatrician in Rochester, N.Y., has seen hundreds of children with obesity over the years in his medical practice. He finally may have a treatment for their medical condition — the powerful weight loss drug Wegovy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle
title: Lesson Plan: ‘Noise Could Take Years Off Your Life. Here’s Why.’
description: In this lesson, students will learn about the dangers of noise in daily life, and the health risks excessive noise can pose. Then, they will document the noise levels in their own communities.
content: Featured article: “Noise Could Take Years Off Your Life. Here’s Why.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Ephrat Livni
title: U.S. Raises Concern Over Israel’s Possible Use of U.S.-Supplied White Phosphorus
description: The Biden administration said it would be asking questions about reports of Israel illegally using white phosphorus in Lebanon in October. Israel denied the claims.
content: The Biden administration said on Monday that it is looking into reports by Amnesty International and The Washington Post that Israel used white phosphorus supplied by the United States in violation of international law.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Yale Condemns Hanging of Palestinian Flag on New Haven Menorah
description: Yale University leaders, elected officials and pro-Palestinian activists said the brief action during a weekend protest crossed a line.
content: Yale University leaders, elected officials and clergy in New Haven, Conn., condemned what they called the desecration of a public Hanukkah menorah after a protester briefly hung a Palestinian flag from it over the weekend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: This Easy Dish Takes a Can of Curry Paste and Runs With It
description: Toasted spices and ground peanuts turn a pantry staple into the base of a plush panang curry.
content: A jar or can of Thai curry paste is a pungent gateway to so many excellent weeknight meals. Mixed with coconut milk and simmered with vegetables, tofu or meat, it’s one of those ebullient pantry hacks that breathes extra life into any ingredient it touches.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Orlando Mayorquin
title: You’ll Pay More to See the Mona Lisa: The Louvre Is Raising Its Admission Price
description: The increase, going into effect in January, comes amid broader concerns about rising costs for lodging and transportation ahead of the Summer Olympics in Paris.
content: The Louvre Museum said it would raise its basic ticket price to 22 euros from 17 euros beginning next month in the latest sign that visitors may face higher costs ahead of next year’s Summer Olympics in Paris.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tressie McMillan Cottom
title: This Economy Has Bigger Problems Than ‘Bad Vibes’
description: The act of working needs to become more affordable and accessible.
content: The economy is growing. Wages are up. Unemployment is low. Income inequality is narrowing. The fearmongering about inflation proved to be, well, wrong. According to many economy watchers, Americans should be sending the Biden administration a gift basket full of positive vibes — and votes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Yaffe-Bellany
title: The Power Vacuum at the Top of the Crypto Industry
description: A year ago, Sam Bankman-Fried and Changpeng Zhao ran two of the largest crypto companies. As they grapple with legal woes, others are jockeying to lead the industry’s next chapter.
content: The price of Bitcoin is surging again. Major financial firms are showing renewed interest in digital currencies. And crypto fanatics are celebrating the end of a long period of depressed prices and business collapses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Trump Gains in Iowa Poll, and DeSantis Holds Off Haley for a Distant Second
description: Mr. Trump has a commanding lead over his rivals five weeks before the first-in-the-nation caucuses.
content: Multiple Republicans have ended their presidential campaigns over the past two months, narrowing the field against former President Donald J. Trump — but the only person who has gained much ground in the first voting state is Mr. Trump, according to a new poll.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ernesto Londoño
title: Minneapolis Man Is Freed After Serving 19 Years on Murder Charge
description: Marvin Haynes has long maintained he was wrongfully convicted in a 2004 homicide. Prosecutors recently concluded he was right.
content: Moments after a Minneapolis jury found Marvin Haynes guilty of the May 2004 killing of a flower shop clerk, he cried out in protest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Ateez Is the Fourth K-Pop Group With a No. 1 Album in 2023
description: The eight-member boy band debuts atop the Billboard 200 this week, following Tomorrow X Together, NewJeans and Stray Kids.
content: This week on the music charts, Ateez becomes the latest K-pop act to score the top album with a menu of collectible packages, while Brenda Lee’s 65-year-old chestnut “Rockin’ Around the Christmas Tree” holds as the No. 1 single on her 79th birthday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clifford Krauss
title: Occidental Is Latest Oil Company to Buy a Smaller Producer
description: The oil company said it would buy CrownRock for $12 billion just weeks after Exxon Mobil and Chevron announced acquisitions.
content: Occidental Petroleum on Monday joined the consolidation wave that is sweeping the U.S. oil industry by offering to buy CrownRock, a privately owned oil producer, for $12 billion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Yoon
title: How I Learned to Spend Money on Love
description: I didn’t see the point of investing in candlelit dinners or surprise gifts. Then I met Nicki, who taught me that romance is not an extravagance.
content: This essay is part of a Modern Love project on the intersection of money and relationships.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: Still Annoyed at Biden, New Hampshire Democrats Gear Up to Help Him
description: Despite being bumped down the presidential calendar, Democrats in the state are planning a write-in campaign for the president, who won’t be on New Hampshire primary ballots.
content: New Hampshire Democrats were furious at President Biden when he shook up the party’s nominating calendar last year, diminishing their state’s political importance by pushing its primary election behind South Carolina’s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Celedonia Jones, Self-Educated New York Historian, Dies at 93
description: He served as Manhattan borough historian from 1997 to 2005. He also dug deeply into the history of Seneca Village, a mostly Black settlement in what became Central Park.
content: One day last year, Celedonia Jones, a charismatic, self-educated historian, stood on a patch of land in Manhattan that in the 19th century was within Seneca Village, a largely Black community of about 300 people that would become part of Central Park.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Monday Briefing
description: Conditions worsen in Gaza.
content: Tens of thousands of Palestinians have gathered near Gaza’s border with Egypt, as they attempt to flee Israel’s complete siege of the Gaza Strip. Aid officials warned that conditions were “dire” amid “extreme” overcrowding, and they have raised alarms about the spread of disease and the risk of a potential mass displacement into Egypt.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson
title: Biden Administration Chooses Military Supplier for First Chips Act Grant
description: The award, which will go to BAE Systems, is part of a new government program aimed at creating a more secure supply of semiconductors.
content: The Biden administration announced on Monday that BAE Systems, a defense contractor, will receive the first federal grant from a new program aimed at shoring up American manufacturing of critical semiconductors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ameera Harouda, Ben Hubbard and Vivian Nereim
title: Gazans Mass at Border for Safety, but Find Only More Peril
description: As Israeli forces pound Gaza, the area where Palestinians can seek shelter is shrinking, raising concerns that they could be forced into Egypt.
content: The last point of refuge for Palestinians fleeing from Israel’s relentless siege of Gaza is collapsing under the weight of tens of thousands of people seeking food and shelter, stirring fears of a potential mass displacement into Egypt, United Nations officials warned on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mary Pipher
title: Finding Light in Winter
description: No matter how dark the days, we can find light in our own hearts, and we can be one another’s light.
content: The mornings are dark, the late afternoons are dusky, and before we finish making dinner, the daylight is gone. As we approach the darkest days of the year, we’re confronted with the darkness of wars, a dysfunctional government, fentanyl deaths, mass shootings and reports of refugees crawling through the Darién Gap or floundering in small boats in the Mediterranean. And we cannot avoid the tragedy of climate change with its droughts, floods, fires and hurricanes. Indeed, the world is pummeled with misfortune.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: surreptitiously
description: This word has appeared in 67 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word surreptitiously has appeared in 67 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Oct. 23 in “How to Win Your Next UNO Game” by Deb Amlen:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise, Carlos Prieto, Rachelle Bonja, Stella Tan, M.J. Davis Lin, Marc Georges, Marion Lozano, Dan Powell and Chris Wood
title: Can an ‘Anarcho-Capitalist’ President Save Argentina’s Economy?
description: Argentina’s new leader, Javier Milei, is a right-wing populist with a radical economic plan.
content: Warning: this episode contains strong language.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes, Eric Schmitt, David E. Sanger and Thomas Gibbons-Neff
title: U.S. and Ukraine Search for a New Strategy After Failed Counteroffensive
description: President Volodymyr Zelensky arrived in Washington at a critical moment, both on the battlefield and on Capitol Hill.
content: American and Ukrainian military leaders are searching for a new strategy that they can begin executing early next year to revive Kyiv’s fortunes and flagging support for the country’s war against Russia, according to U.S. and Ukrainian officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Cowell
title: Glenys Kinnock, Political Force in Britain and Europe, Dies at 79
description: The wife of the Labour leader Neil Kinnock, she carved her own leftist identity with a seat in the European Parliament and as a British government minister.
content: Glenys Kinnock, a former European lawmaker and British government minister who helped secure for women a central role in the continent’s politics, died on Dec. 3 at her home in London. She was 79.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka and Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: Skull of Ancient ‘Sea Monster’ With Dagger-Like Teeth Discovered in England
description: The six-foot-long fossil could offer new clues about the pliosaur, known as the largest carnivorous reptile to ever live.
content: In the spring of 2022, Philip Jacobs, an artist and fossil hunter, was walking along the Jurassic Coast in southern England when he came across a snout.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: How Do You Unwind During the Holidays?
description: Give us your best advice.
content: Every day in The Evening newsletter, we try to bring to readers a collection of stories, recipes and things to do at the end of the day that will help them wind down. Now, as we head into the busy holiday season, we’re looking for advice. We’re asking readers: Do you have a unique way of unwinding during the holidays?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Vic Davalillo, Venezuelan All-Star and Gold Glove Winner, Is Dead
description: Over 16 seasons in the major leagues, he won two World Series titles in the 1970s and had a reliable bat. He was revered in his native country.
content: Vic Davalillo, a two-time World Series champion who spent 16 seasons in the major leagues and won a Gold Glove as an outfielder, died on Wednesday in Caracas, Venezuela. He was 84 or 87; sources differ on his age.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hirsch and Stacy Cowley
title: Investor Group Is Said to Value Macy’s at $5.8 Billion in Offer
description: Department stores have been a frequent target of takeover attempts by investors looking to take advantage of prime real estate.
content: An investor group has submitted a bid for the famed department store chain Macy’s that would take the retailer private at a value of $5.8 billion, according to a person familiar with the bid, more than $1 billion over its current market value.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Karaian, Jeanna Smialek and Joe Rennison
title: Corporate America Is Testing the Limits of Its Pricing Power
description: Firms may struggle to keep profits up if demand slows, but so far they are finding ways to keep margins wide.
content: Alexander MacKay coleads the Pricing Lab at Harvard Business School, a research center devoted to studying how companies set prices. Since the pandemic, he has watched how businesses have become more willing to experiment with what they charge their customers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth A. Harris
title: Jennifer Finney Boylan to Lead PEN America
description: The author and L.G.B.T.Q. rights advocate will take the helm of the free expression organization at a time when challenges to books and to free speech are on the rise.
content: Jennifer Finney Boylan, an author and L.G.B.T.Q. rights advocate, was elected on Monday president of PEN America, one of the most significant organizations defending free speech in the country. She will lead the PEN board of trustees at a time when challenges to books and free expression are on the rise.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karoun Demirjian and Charlie Savage
title: House Plan to Vote on Extension of Disputed Surveillance Law Collapses
description: A fight over an expiring national security law descended into disorder on the eve of an expected vote on rival bills to reauthorize and overhaul it.
content: The House scrapped votes on rival bills late Monday that would narrow the scope of a powerful surveillance tool after an ugly fight broke out among Republicans, likely punting until next year on plans to renew but also limit an expiring wiretapping law at the heart of the program.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman
title: Texas Supreme Court Rules Against Woman Who Sought Court-Approved Abortion
description: Hours before the ruling, a group representing the woman, whose fetus received a fatal diagnosis, said she was leaving Texas for an abortion.
content: The Texas Supreme Court on Monday overturned a lower court order allowing an abortion for a pregnant woman whose fetus was diagnosed with a fatal condition, hours after her lawyers said she had decided to leave Texas for the procedure in the face of the state’s abortion bans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Turns Away Challenge to Law Banning Conversion Therapy
description: Washington State, like more than 20 other states, bars licensed therapists from trying to change the sexual orientation or gender identity of minors in their care.
content: The Supreme Court said on Monday that it would not hear a First Amendment challenge to a Washington State law banning professional counseling services intended to change a minor’s gender identity or sexual orientation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy W. Peters, Dana Goldstein and Rob Copeland
title: As Harvard President Faces Pressure to Resign, Some Faculty Show Support
description: Claudine Gay, Harvard’s president, faced rising pressure after her answers to questions about antisemitism. Some faculty members signed a petition supporting her.
content: The president of Harvard University, Claudine Gay, faced escalating pressure on Sunday to resign as prominent alumni, donors and politicians called for her ouster. But a group of faculty members rallied to support her, arguing that she was being railroaded for a moment of poorly worded remarks about antisemitism.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: Bob Dylan Sings, and Talks, on These Tapes From 62 Years Ago
description: An auction house is selling the three reels, which come from a recording session for Dylan’s first album.
content: Good morning. It’s Monday. Today we will find out how a sculptor in Detroit came to have master tapes of Bob Dylan’s first album. They could sell for as much as $1.2 million at an auction this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jancee Dunn
title: Sign Up for Well’s 6-Day Energy Challenge
description: Set yourself up for an invigorating new year.
content: Would you like more energy as you go about your day? We’ll bet the answer is yes. Whether you’re younger or older, working or retired, raising a family or living solo, most of us could use more vigor in our lives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: David Mamet, a.k.a. ‘Embittered Dave,’ Would Like a Word
description: In a new memoir, the filmmaker and playwright shares his opinions on Hollywood past and present.
content: David Mamet’s best plays have impeccable titles: “American Buffalo,” “Glengarry Glen Ross,” “Speed-the-Plow,” “Oleanna.” So does his best nonfiction book, “Writing in Restaurants.” Now, late in his career, comes a miscellany called “Everywhere an Oink Oink.” Oh, boy. Here we go.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Tuesday Briefing: An Israeli Warning to Hezbollah
description: Plus, the debate over who’s a “colonizer.”
content: Top Israeli officials have warned that increased Hezbollah attacks on northern Israel carried out from Lebanon could prompt a powerful response, as Israeli troops waged street battles against Hamas in Gaza.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abdi Latif Dahir
title: Kenya Suffers Third Major Power Blackout in Four Months
description: The outages have raised widespread concerns in a country already grappling with discontent over a worsening economic situation.
content: Kenya’s government said on Monday that it was gradually restoring power after the country’s third major blackout in four months, adding to rising discontent with President William Ruto over a worsening economic situation and his policies since taking office 15 months ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Saul, Alan Blinder, Maureen Farrell and Anemona Hartocollis
title: Inside the Chaotic Struggle for Power at Penn
description: For months, donors waged a campaign against the president and the chairman of the board. After the hearings on antisemitism, a dissident group of trustees had seen enough.
content: The dissident trustees of the University of Pennsylvania’s board had decided to meet in secret over the weekend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Green
title: Review: In ‘How to Dance in Ohio,’ Making Autism Sing
description: A musical about seven autistic young adults, played by seven autistic young actors, breaks new ground on Broadway.
content: It would have been enough of a first for a Broadway musical to tell a respectful or even vaguely authentic story about autistic people. On the rare occasions we have seen such characters represented in commercial productions, they have mostly been objects of pity, mockery or fear.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $2.4 Million Homes in California
description: A 1926 stone house in Palm Springs, a midcentury-modern home in Los Angeles and a three-structure compound in Sea Ranch.
content: This house, made of locally quarried stone, is in the Araby Cove neighborhood. It was built as a retreat for the Giannini family, who founded the Bank of Italy in San Francisco, now known as Bank of America. In the mid-1980s, the well-known modernist Albert Frey was commissioned to add a carport with an expansive roof deck on top, offering panoramic views of the desert landscape.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: Gazans Mass at Border, and Pressure Rises on Harvard’s President
description: Hear the news in five minutes.
content: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak and Alan Feuer
title: Special Counsel Asks Supreme Court to Decide if Trump Is Immune From Prosecution
description: The special counsel, Jack Smith, urged the justices to move with exceptional speed, and they quickly agreed to fast-track the first phase of the case.
content: Jack Smith, the special counsel prosecuting former President Donald J. Trump on charges of plotting to overturn the 2020 election, asked the Supreme Court on Monday to rule on Mr. Trump’s argument that he is immune from prosecution. The justices quickly agreed to fast-track the first phase of the case.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Border Clampdown Severs an Arizona Lifeline
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, December 11, 2023.
content: “Everything going on here is better than what’s happening in my country.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Vognar
title: Synanon and Love Has Won, Two Cults With New Docs
description: “Born in Synanon” and “Love Has Won: The Cult of Mother God” join a crowded field of cult documentaries, but diverge from the usual template.
content: One week it’s a pair of online matchmaking hucksters, the next, a group of zonked-out seekers waiting for the spaceships to arrive. There are sex cults (“The Vow”), and doomsday cults (“Waco: American Apocalypse”), and cults that seem to exist for no obvious reason other than being cults. Turn on a TV or fire up a streaming service and you will encounter a docu-series about a group of desperate people rallying around a charismatic and often deranged leader.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins
title: Donald Tusk Chosen as Poland’s Prime Minister After Rival Is Rejected
description: Parliament shot down a new government proposed by the caretaker prime minister, Mateusz Morawiecki, whose party, Law and Justice, lost its parliamentary majority in an October election.
content: Poland’s newly elected Parliament torpedoed a long-shot effort by right-wing forces to stay in power and chose the opposition leader Donald Tusk as the nation’s new prime minister on Monday. The decision ushers the biggest and most populous country on the European Union’s formerly communist eastern flank into a new era.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Sherman
title: Joyce Season to Include Commemoration of Max Roach
description: The Joyce Theater’s spring/summer season will feature a new work by Ronald K. Brown and a tribute to Chicago house music from Rennie Harris.
content: The Joyce Theater will honor the drummer, composer and activist Max Roach with a centennial celebration as part of its spring/summer season, the theater announced on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shivani Gonzalez
title: What’s on TV This Week: Christmas Specials and a ‘Vanderpump Rules’ Recap
description: Several networks present holiday-themed specials, and Bravo airs “A Decade of Rumors and Lies,” hosted by Lisa Vanderpump.
content: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, Dec. 11-17. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Nehamas
title: DeSantis Accuses Trump of ‘Cowardice’ for Refusing to Debate Rivals
description: Gov. Ron DeSantis escalated his attacks on the former president after Mr. Trump bragged about debating Hillary Clinton in 2016.
content: Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida accused former President Donald J. Trump of “cowardice” for refusing to participate in the Republican presidential primary debates after Mr. Trump boasted about facing Hillary Clinton in 2016 following the release of the “Access Hollywood” tape.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chloé Cooper Jones
title: Can Love Overcome the ‘Cost’ of Care?
description: My disability means I’ll need long-term care. If I pay for more now, will my boyfriend care for me later?
content: This essay is part of a Modern Love project on the intersection of money and relationships.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Moses
title: This Christmas, ‘Whamageddon’ Will Save You From Tears
description: Are you in need of another Christmas tradition, and a bit of fun? Enter: “Whamageddon.”
content: Listening to Christmas music can bring people together. Not listening to a particular Christmas song, it turns out, can have the same effect.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: How NASA Learned to Love 4 Squirmy Letters
description: Decades after sending it to design purgatory, the space agency celebrates a logo it still calls the worm.
content: Last month, NASA welcomed Richard Danne to its headquarters in Washington to celebrate work he had done nearly half a century ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: Skepticism of Digital Currency Needs to Be Taken Seriously
description: Central bankers are plowing ahead with the technology, but the potential for backlash is high.
content: The world’s central banks are moving briskly, and it would seem inexorably, toward introducing digital forms of cash. But I think they are underestimating the backlash from people who worry that digital currencies issued by central banks will become instruments of government control over their lives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Elite Universities Face Turmoil Over Antisemitism Concerns
description: Also, Trump’s immunity argument heads to the Supreme Court. Here’s the latest at the end of Monday.
content: At Harvard, students, faculty, alumni and donors debated today over the future of the school’s leadership. Claudine Gay, the university’s president, was facing calls to resign after widely criticized comments she made last week about antisemitism on campus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Baker
title: To Revive Portland, Officials Seek to Ban Public Drug Use
description: State and local leaders are proposing to roll back part of the nation’s pioneering drug decriminalization law and step up police enforcement.
content: After years of rising overdoses and an exodus of business from central Portland, Gov. Tina Kotek of Oregon said on Monday that state and city officials are proposing to roll back a portion of the nation’s most wide-ranging drug decriminalization law in a bid to revive the troubled city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: ‘Are You Going to Be the One to Get Rid of Santa?’
description: A family in a small town in New York holds a world record for having the most lights on a residential property to the dismay of some neighbors and the delight of others.
content: On a winding country road, four miles from the nearest traffic light in rural Dutchess County, N.Y., the holiday lights appear like a carnival fun house shattering the darkness.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Penn, Stanley Reed and Brad Plumer
title: What Ails Offshore Wind: Supply Chains, Ships and Interest Rates
description: Government officials and energy developers misjudged the difficulty of building huge clean energy projects in the United States, which has built very few of them.
content: A few years ago, interest in offshore wind energy was so strong that developers proposed spending tens of billions of dollars to plunk hundreds of turbines the size of skyscrapers in the Atlantic Ocean from Maine to Virginia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: I Have to Buy New Jeans. Help!
description: A reader seeks guidance for navigating the overwhelming and environmentally destructive denim market.
content: The irony of finding the perfect pair of jeans is that its very discovery contains the seeds of its destruction. After all, once you’ve found your ideal jeans, you wear them, over and over again, until, no matter how hardy they are, you wear them out. And then you’re stuck with the horrible task of trying to replace them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mya Guarnieri and Sebastian Castrodad
title: Finding a Way Back to ‘Perfect Beach’
description: On the spectacular northern coast of Puerto Rico, a writer’s favorite stretch of golden sand beckoned, but getting there legally would take some creativity.
content: On the northern coast of Puerto Rico — about an hour’s drive west of San Juan, off a wisp of a road threaded through dense green foliage — there exists a long, empty beach that has haunted my dreams for years. On Google Maps, it appears as Punta Caracoles Beach, but I have always thought of it as Perfect Beach.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mae Ngai
title: Ron DeSantis ‘Banned China From Buying Land in the State of Florida.’ How Did We Get Here?
description: Several states have passed new versions of alien land laws, which were popular in the late 19th and early 20th centuries.
content: In the late 1950s, my parents tried to buy land in northern New Jersey on which to build a home. But no one would sell to them. A real estate agent said it was because they were Chinese.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Bad Blood: A Timeline of the Swift-West-Kardashian Feud
description: After 14 years, a new interview suggests this dispute may keep giving us new chapters.
content: Alexander Hamilton and Aaron Burr. Joan Crawford and Bette Davis. Optimus Prime and Megatron.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Rosenberg
title: A Closer Look at Three Hamas Strongholds Targeted by Israel
description: Israeli forces were engaged in intense battles on Monday in Khan Younis, Jabaliya and Shajaiye.
content: With Israel pressing its offensive in Gaza, its forces were engaged in intense battles on Monday in three areas of the strip where Israeli officials believe Hamas militants still have strongholds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenna Russell
title: In Maine, a Mother’s Lonely Quest for Her Missing Son
description: Tammy Lacher Scully’s adult son disappeared 18 months ago from a psychiatric hospital in Bangor. It has fallen on her to keep the search going.
content: For nine straight mornings last December, and again in the fading light of dusk, Tammy Lacher Scully left her home in Belfast, Maine, and drove a mile to the convenience store that doubles as a bus station.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neal E. Boudette
title: U.A.W. Accuses Honda, Hyundai and Volkswagen of Labor Violations
description: A week after declaring a drive to organize nonunion automakers, the United Automobile Workers union filed charges against three foreign manufacturers.
content: The United Automobile Workers union accused three foreign automakers on Monday of unfair labor practices, asserting that they had interfered with efforts by employees to build support for the union at U.S. plants.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: Piecing Together a Black Identity, and a Whole Black World
description: “Multiplicity,” like so many of the artworks it features, spills out from the tight frame of the Frist Art Museum itself.
content: One of the greatest astonishments of “Multiplicity: Blackness in Contemporary Collage,” on display through Dec. 31 at the Frist Art Museum in Nashville, is that no major institution has ever before mounted a comprehensive showcase of work by Black collage artists. One of the most original things about the exhibition, in other words, is the fact of its existence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catrin Einhorn
title: A Quarter of Freshwater Fish Are at Risk of Extinction, a New Assessment Finds
description: A global update from the leading authority on the status of species shows that climate change is compounding other threats to plants and animals.
content: A quarter of the world’s freshwater fish are at risk of extinction, according to the first comprehensive assessment of the animals by the world’s leading scientific authority on the status of species.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eileen Sullivan
title: In Court With the Women He Defamed, Giuliani Faces Millions in Damages
description: Two Georgia election workers are seeking as much as $43 million for false assertions from Rudolph Giuliani that they had sought to swing the 2020 outcome against Donald Trump.
content: Rudolph W. Giuliani’s lawyer told jurors on Monday that the tens of millions of dollars in damages two Georgia election workers are seeking from him in a defamation suit “will be the end of Mr. Giuliani,” likening an award of that scale to a civil death penalty.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Dwyer
title: The Nation Magazine to Become Monthly
description: The progressive publication will move to the new schedule in January, and each issue will be 84 pages instead of 48.
content: The Nation, the progressive magazine that has published since 1865, will publish monthly instead of every other week starting in January.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Badger, Ben Blatt and Josh Katz
title: Why Are So Many American Pedestrians Dying at Night?
description: Nothing resembling this pattern has occurred in other comparably wealthy countries.
content: Nothing resembling this pattern has occurred in other comparably wealthy countries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. D. Biersdorfer
title: Do You Know These Novels With Academic Settings?
description: Try this short literary geography quiz that tests your knowledge of books with college connections.
content: Try this short literary geography quiz that tests your knowledge of books with college connections.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quiz: Are You a Climate Nerd?
description: Test your climate news knowledge with this seven-question quiz as the COP28 climate summit heads into the home stretch.
content: Test your climate news knowledge with this seven-question quiz as the COP28 climate summit heads into the home stretch.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Taboo but True: Readers Share How Money Affects Relationships
description: Readers share how money affected their relationships
content: Readers share how money affected their relationships
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Camille Elemia and Nailah Morgan
title: Chinese Ship Fires Water Cannon at Philippine Vessel
description: Video captured by a Times reporter showed how China attempted to prevent Filipino fishers from gaining access to Scarborough Shoal in the disputed South China Sea.
content: Video captured by a Times reporter showed how China attempted to prevent Filipino fishers from gaining access to Scarborough Shoal in the disputed South China Sea.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Bronx Apartment Building Partially Collapses
description: A seven-story residential building in the Morris Heights neighborhood of the Bronx partially collapsed.
content: A seven-story residential building in the Morris Heights neighborhood of the Bronx partially collapsed.
source.name: The New York Times
